title: house of lords abolished poll house of lords brexit vote
story: More than 2,700 readers have voted in the Express.co.uk poll as of 10.40pm, with almost all backing a move to for the upper house of UK parliament to be abolished.And just four percent of readers polled said they wanted to keep the House of Lords which this week has threatened to derail Brexit.One Express.co.uk reader said: &ldquoLet&rsquos have a referendum on abolishing the House of Lords now.Another added: &ldquoIt&rsquos time for this den of unelected parasites (the Lords) to go.&ldquoThey have always served their own greed.A petition calling for the House of Lords to be scrapped and replaced with a new elected body hit 100,000 votes earlier this year potentially triggering a Commons debate.A massive 96 percent of Express readers have voted to abolish the House of Lords                Theresa May faces ANOTHER Brexit customs union showdown with rebels                Farage hits out at Boris Johnson and Gove for 'Brexit betrayal'But Whitehall said the Government recognises the importance of House of Lords reform but that the issue was not a priority in this Parliament.The response added: Where there are further measures that can command consensus from across the House, the Government would welcome working with peers to look at how to take them forward.The resounding result comes after Prime Minister Theresa May suffered a bruising setback to her Brexit plans in a crunch House of Lords vote on Wednesday evening, with Lords voting 348 to 225 in favour of changing the EU Withdrawal Bill legislation.A cross-party alliance of Lords, including Tory rebels, put forward an amendment to the Bill in a move that could leave the door open for Britain to remain in the customs union, despite the Prime Minister ruling it out.If such a move were to be forced, it would destroy Britain&rsquos chances of being able to strike post-Brexit trade deals with several countries across the world, including the US and Australia.Michael Gove rejected suggestions Britain could remain in the customs unionSpeaking on the BBC&rsquos Today programme, Environment Secretary and leading Brexiteer Michael Gove rejected suggestions Britain would be forced to back down and remain in the customs union.&ldquoI listened with interest to some of the contributions to the debate but I think that it&rsquos important to always listen to what the House of Lords says.&ldquoBut the House of Commons has been very clear. The British people were very clear in the referendum.&ldquoWe are leaving the European Union. Leaving the European Union also means taking back control of our borders and our trade.Mr Gove added: &ldquoBeing able to sign our own free trade deals is a compelling and persuasive one.&ldquoI know that when that case is put to the House of Commons it will rally Conservative MPs and others behind it.&ldquoA case endorsed by 17.4 million people in the referendum and one the Government has pledged to honour.Labour&rsquos Yvette Cooper and Tory Nicky Morgan have also now drafted a motion that urges Mrs May to include an &ldquoeffective customs union in her Brexit negotiations.Senior Tories fear the latest reverse in the House of Lords could be the start of a series of defeats during the Lords Report Stage of the legislation, with a hardcore group of Remain-backing having tabled dozens more amendments.Analysis by the Change Britain pressure group has revealed that 10 fanatical Remain-backing peers have proposed a total of 338 amendments aimed at frustrating or even reversing the country&rsquos departure from the EU.The research from the group, which wants a full break with Brussels, showed that Labour peer Lord Judd had tabled a massive 62 amendments to the EU Withdrawal Bill, which is designed to transfer EU law into the UK to ensure a smooth Brexit process.Fellow Labour peer Lord Adonis had tabled 59 amendments while Lib Dem Lord Wallace of Tankerness was responsible for 49 of them.

story: However, MEPs from across the political spectrum with eurosceptic and pro-European politicians have joined up to build a consensus that will ultimately protect the European Union as well as their own agendas.Nigel Farage&rsquos EFDD group houses 45 MEPs who are critical of the EU in their own different ways, while Parliament&rsquos largest group the EPP has 219 representatives wholeheartedly behind the Brussels project &ndash including two British Remainers who left their fellow Conservatives to rejoin the EPP in 2017.While Jean-Claude Juncker&rsquos European Commission is the body handling Brexit negotiations on behalf of the EU, MEPs in Parliament will vote on recommendations of how they see Brexit progressing.Their views will remain important as they will have a decisive say on the final agreement between the EU and UK in the shape of a Parliament-wide vote.But what do different MEPs from across the European Parliament actually want from Brexit and how will their opinions shape the UK&rsquos orce from Brussels?MEPs from across the political spectrum are ided over Brexit                Hartley-Brewer in brutal Lord Adonis slap down after Lords Brexit vote                IDS explains why EU single market bad for UK in fiery Lords crackdownHans Olaf-Henkel says the UK has common sense and wants to offer a solution to keep us in the EUHans-Olaf Henkel, Germany, European Conservative and Reformist Group.This senior MEP sits alongside the majority of the EU Parliament&rsquos British Conservative politicians, and has a distinct view on how Brexit should pan out.Mr Henkel, one of Parliament&rsquos anti-federalists, is a critic of Brexit but does not pin the blame on the UK for the decision.The German argues that key EU players Michel Barnier and Guy Verhofstadt did not help the cause with their criticism of the Brexit campaign.He is now leading a one-man crusade to offer Britain a new EU deal in the hope Westminster will opt to reverse the Brexit decision and rejoin the EU.Jean-Claude Juncker greets colleagues with kisses and slaps 1 of 16Mr Henkel told Express.co.uk: &ldquoFor me, Britain is the last country with common sense in the European Union, when Britain leaves we&rsquore losing an ally for reasonability.He added: &ldquoThe values the British stand for are values Europe should stand for.&ldquoYou like competitiveness, they like harmonisation. You like ersity, they like equality. You like self-responsibility for a country&rsquos state of bank debts, they want to socialise them.&ldquoThe whole EU, itself, is becoming over time a much less attractive, competitive place. If we lose Britain we are in a really bad shape.Because of this, Mr Henkel believes it is time the EU make &ldquoBritain a new offer, an offer that Britain can&rsquot refuse, an offer that gives Britain what they always wanted.Gabriele Zimmer is on the Brexit Steering Group and says the EU needs to understand the Brexit voteGabriele Zimmer, Germany, Confederal Group of the European United Left &ndash Nordic Green LeftMrs Zimmer is of the European Parliament&rsquos most influential MEPs when it comes to Brexit because of the German&rsquos position on the Brexit Steering Group.As one of the Steering Group&rsquos members, Mrs Zimmer has some of the biggest say when it comes to shaping the European Parliament&rsquos Brexit policy.Using her ties to the left, Mrs Zimmer hopes to create a socially driven Brexit which is in the interest of citizens both in Britain and in the remaining EU27.Speaking to Express.co.uk, the German insisted her movement would never seek to punish Britain for Brexit.She said: &ldquoBetween the different political groups we have different positions to the EU and different positions to the referendum, or in which way we should react to the referendum.&ldquoWe as the left, our position is we have to think about the reasons why the majority of the voters decided for a Brexit &ndash why they think the European Union would be reason for criticism of their daily lives and the conditions they have.&ldquoI&rsquom not sharing a position to say the people in the 27 other member states they see the consequences and the impact of the Brexit on the daily lives for people in Great Britain &ndash and that&rsquos why they remain in the European Union, I don&rsquot think this is a good approach.&ldquoI think we have to do more for our common solidarity inside the Union &ndash for a better Union, a more social Union, for more democracy inside the Union. That is the way we have to go and we have to do a lot to change things here in the Union.&ldquoThat&rsquos why my group are saying we don&rsquot want to punish Britain for their decision to leave the EU.Mrs Zimmer maintains her movement are bringing both the welfare of EU and British citizens to the Steering Group when discussing Brexit.REUTERSGuy Verhofstadt is an outspoken critic of BrexitGuy Verhofstadt, Belgium, Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for EuropeThe former Belgian prime minister is the chairman of the European Parliament&rsquos Brexit Steering Group and one of the most outspoken critics of the orce.With an influential role, he uses his position in Parliament to strike a deal which he sees will benefit the EU and its remaining member states.An advocate for the rights of EU citizens who wish to remain in Britain after Brexit, Mr Verhofstadt has used the Windrush case to demand a series of meeting with the British Home Office to ensure EU citizens&rsquo rights are respected as per the agreement in Phase One of negotiations.Mr Verhofstadt warned EU citizens could face a &ldquobureaucratic nightmare after Brexit in the wake of the UK&rsquos handling of the Windrush generation &ndash immigrants who moved from the Caribbean to Britain over 50 years ago.Despite being legally entitled to live in the UK, the Windrush generation have suffered difficulties when finding work and accessing benefits and healthcare in the UK.The Belgian MEP told Parliament: &ldquoCertainly after the Windrush scandal in Britain, we want to be sure the same is not happening to our European citizens and that there is no bureaucratic nightmare there.Florian Philippot is an ally of Nigel Farage who is working for Frexit, tooFlorian Philippot, France, Europe of Freedom and Direct DemocracyAn ally of leading Brexiteer Nigel Farage, Mr Philippot is a critic of the EU and attempts to create a more integrated Union.When French President Emmanuel Macron presented his plans to reform the bloc, Mr Philippot presented one of the only challenges to his countryman.He denounced the French President for wanting a EU that disregards the risk of terrorism and migration.Mr Philippot added: &ldquoThe British people, whether you like it or not, sovereignly voted in favour of independence and freedom.&ldquoThe European Union is the past.And in one final blow, he declared: &ldquoLong live Frexit and long live a free France.Philippe Lamberts is a pro-European and says we can't keep the Good Friday Agreement and have BrexitPhilippe Lamberts, Belgium, Group of the Greens &ndash European Free AllianceThe Belgian MEP is another member of the Brexit Steering Group and a pro-European politician.Using his position he has been seeking protection of the Good Friday Agreement and the prevention of a hard border emerging on the island of Ireland.Mr Lamberts has even gone as far to suggest the Irish border question could see Britain one day rejoin the European Union.He believes Theresa May&rsquos commitment to preventing a hard border leaves the British Prime Minister with little choice but to consider EU membership for her country once again.Mr Lambert&rsquos said: &ldquoIf &ndash and it&rsquos a big if &ndash the UK wants to keep the Good Friday Agreement, the only satisfactory option is full EU membership.&ldquoThat is the only logical conclusion.

story: The country&rsquos foreign minister Julie Bishop hit out at Remainer politicians for their plot to keep Britain shackled to the bloc after Brexit, thus thwarting her vision for &ldquoenormous of no-confidence letters from Brexitbacking MPs, which would likely trigger a leadership challenge.One Conservative backbencher said: &ldquoIf there's a cave-in on the customs union, I think there will be a leadership challenge.Up to 48 letters are required for a leadership battle, according to Conservative Party rules.Mrs May had insisted Britain will leave the EU customs market following Brexit to prompt trade deals across the globe.PROSIT PHOTOTalks have sparked a growing sense of panic and anger in Brussels, Dublin, Belfast and WestminsterYesterday, the EU blasted every single Irish border proposal, sparking fears Brexit talks are on the brink of collapse.The question of how Britain can balance an open Irish border while pulling Northern Ireland from the customs union and single market appeared to be the one issue which could bring the Brexit process screeching to a halt.Leaders in Dublin, Belfast and Brussels spent much of the lead-up to the June 2016 referendum issuing increasingly desperate warnings about the Irish border, which has been &lsquoinvisible&rsquo and free of customs and police checks since the 1990s.Adding more controversy and confusion is the DUP, who prop up Mrs May&rsquos minority government.Leader Arlene Foster said she will not accept anything other than Northern Ireland leaving the EU on the same terms as England, Wales and Scotland, ruling out a solution which would see the Republic and Northern Ireland become economically aligned.Mrs May had insisted Britain will leave the EU customs market following BrexitTalks continue - albeit with a growing sense of panic and anger in Brussels, Dublin, Belfast and Westminster.Today, the PM is meeting with Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull.Yesterday, The Commonwealth Heads of Government met at Windsor Castle where they discussed whether Prince Charles should succeed the Queen as head of the 53-nation alliance.

title: IVF twins hen s egg seven years
story: PHSarah and Tony Elder pictured on holiday with their &lsquomiracle&rsquo twins, aged fourSarah Elder thought she would never become a mother after trying for seven years to fall pregnant. Archie and Scarlett were born after their parents spent more than &pound25,000 on failed fertility treatment.Mrs Elder, 42, who lives with landscaper husband Tony, 49, in the Isle of Man, said: I can't believe I finally have my twins, it really does seem like a miracle.It has taken so many years of trying and now we are all a family at last. And it's all thanks to the yolk of a hen egg. It seems unbelievable.The couple started trying for a family in 2006 but it wasn't a success. Four years later, they decided to try a course of fertility treatment.                'I feel exploited' Mum speaks out as IVF clinics accused of ignoring                Baby born FOUR YEARS after his parents died in a car crashUKTwins Archie, left, and Scarlett were born after seven years of treatmentThey underwent their first course of IVF in 2010 but that failed and the couple were devastated. Mrs Elder said: We had really thought the treatment would work straight away, so to have found out it had failed was heartbreaking.But we refused to give up hope - we were desperate to become parents so we knew we would just keep trying.The couple had another attempt and Mrs Elder did fall pregnant, but she miscarried the baby a few weeks later.Doctors then recommended trying a different technique. So for the seventh course of fertility treatment, Mrs Elder had an intravenous treatment called intralipid infusion, which involves using yolk from a hen's egg.It works by fatty acids in the egg reducing the number of killer cells in the immune system.Sarah, who works as head of finance and operational services for Hospice Isle of Man, said: I'd never heard of using egg yolk to try and have a baby before, but I was willing to try anything. We'd been trying for a baby for seven years and I didn't know how much more we could both take. We decided we would have one last treatment - it was going to be our last chance.Her pregnancy went smoothly and the twins, who are non-identical as they have each been conceived with a different egg, arrived in November 2013, Scarlett weighing 7lb, and Archie the biggest at 7lb 7oz.Mrs Elder added: It was the most amazing feeling when we finally held them in our arms. After a seven-year battle, we were finally a mum and dad at last.And the four-year-old twins are healthy and happy, said mum.

story: Malcolm Turnbull told the Prime Minister he was pleased with the Government&rsquos interest in joining the TTP after we leave the European Union on March 29, 2019.&nbspMrs&nbspMay stated the two countries are keen to combat protectionism and promote free trade together.&nbspThe Australian PM said: Trade is clearly very high on your agenda, as it always is on ours. Trade means jobs.That's why we persevered with the Trans-Pacific Partnership, got that signed despite the US dropping out.And I'm pleased to see your Government's interest in potentially joining that at a future date when you have left the European Union.&nbspEPAMalcolm Turnbull and Theresa May spoke about the Government's interest in joining the TTP                Britain faces 'MAJOR constitutional crisis' if MPs reject Brexit deal                Brexit News: UK is in talks to sign trade deal worth &pound10TRILLIONThe latest comments come after&nbspMr&nbspTurnbull threw his support behind the&nbspMrs&nbspMay's Brexit plans, claiming he will deploy his own country&rsquos resources to ensure that Britain&rsquos departure from the EU is a success.TTP is a multilateral free trade deal that is aiming to cut 98 percent of tariffs in a marketplace worth &pound10 trillion.Speaking at the Australian Chamber of Commerce in London following the Commonwealth summit,Mr&nbspTurnbull said: &ldquoI believe that whatever the merits of Brexit may be in the UK, that's a domestic debate here, I think it offers greater opportunities for Australia in the UK than ever.&ldquoI can assure you that we will do everything we can to enable the UK to enter into the most favourable, open, to quote President Trump,&nbspfair&nbspand reciprocal trade deal between Australia and the UK.&ldquoWe want an absolute level playing field. And why wouldn't we? Because we think, by and large, as long as there is a level playing field we can always be competitive with the Poms.Mr&nbspTurnbull also hinted Britain could eventually join the TTP post-Brexit, adding:&nbspThe UK has shown real interest in it. Obviously, they'll have to leave the European Union first, but we've had very preliminary discussions, I guess would be the best way of describing it.The UK has shown real interest, and you can see the attraction of it to the&nbspUK,&nbspbecause if they were to join the TPP, they'd be entering into a high-quality trade agreement with 11 other countries in one hit.Now, of course, it'd have to be negotiated with all those 11 other countries including Australia.Nonetheless, it's impressive, I think, to see the strong interest shown by the UK.During today&rsquos meeting at Chequers,&nbspMr&nbspTurnbull and Mrs May also discussed the need for the international community to unite against the threats posed by chemical weapons, cyber attacks&nbspand terrorism.

title: eu news debt euro zone angela merkel germany liable
story: Mrs Merkel, who has abandoned her opposition to a common European deposit insurance aimed at offering protection across the bloc, told reporters at a press conference in Berlin that her countrymen will be liable in the event of it hitting the rocks.Speaking alongside French President Emmanuel Macron, she said: We are also ready to create a joint deposit insurance system in perhaps not the immediate, but more distant future.&nbsp&ldquoWe do want liability and risks to be kept together.&nbspMrs Merkel stressed she was very optimistic that the banking union, involving the transfer of banking policy from the national to the EU level in several member states, could be completed.&nbspGerman Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Emmanuel Macron in Berlin                European Central Bank publishes fresh guidelines for euro banks                 France and Germany vow to LEAD Eurozone reforms But behind the scenes, there is ongoing debate about how far bad loans from banks need to be reduced before European solidarity can be applied to financial institutions in need.Mrs Merkel, who agreed to the banking union in March, said she wants to see a further reduction of the debts and risks of national banks in the EU states.&nbspAt the time she said Germany had always been willing to give up sovereignty, if things could be better regulated by Europe.Her country was also willing to help stabilise the Euro and was prepared for joint euro debt, she added.Angela Merkel has served as German Chancellor since 2005 and Leader of the Christian Democratic Union since 2000. We take a look at her political career in pictures.                    AFPGetty Images1 of 83Angela Merkel through the years The reduction of bad loans is progressing slowly in Europe.&nbspItaly reported the sale of billions of financial investors before its general election in March - but this represents just a fraction of the total of bad loans.German banks are feeling the pressure, with NordLB working hard to solve its capital problem after the takeover of the ailing Bremer Landesbank.Mrs Merkel and Mr Macron said the EU should accept a comprehensive package of reforms in June in areas such as the euro-monetary union and asylum and foreign policy.German banks including NordLb, based in Frankfurt, are feeling the pressureThe possibility of an EU-wide finance minister, and a Eurozone budget have also been floated.She added: We agree that the Eurozone is not yet sufficiently crisis-proof.We bring in some other aspects, but I believe that the sum of our proposals will lead to a good result at the end.&nbspThe pair insisted that by June, they wanted to develop a common position.

Unfortunately, the situation is aggravating there.US outlines RED LINES for better relations with RussiaRussia war: Theresa May assembles A-TEAM to target Russian threatsBusinessman Andrei Kakovkin has already returned from London - and was detained as soon as he arrived back on longstanding allegations he embezzled &pound115,000.But then he was released amid signs the authorities will be lenient.Titov said: This is a totally bogus case.&nbsp&ldquoHopefully, the charges will be dropped before the case is referred to court.Another businessman Konstantin Ivanovich Dyulgerov is hoping for a Moscow court decision to pave the way for his return.&nbspA shop-owning tycoon from Siberia, he backed anti-Putin protesters and faced fraud allegations before going into exile.&nbspLast month influential hawkish retired FSB major-general Aleksandr Mikhailov warned Russians in London they face being subjected to &ldquoHoly inquisition court cases orchestrated by Theresa May.Boris Titov says 34 businessmen have applied to return to RussiaHe said: &ldquoI have an impression that some ancestor of Theresa May's was in the Inquisition because witch hunts have became normal for the UK - and the only target&nbsp is Russian.One businessman on Titov&rsquos list, Sergey Kapchuk, 45, filmed last month flanked by two bodyguards, has now vanished.&nbspVladimir Putin&rsquos 'youth army' has swollen by 150,000 recruits in ONE year                    YunArmia  east2west news1 of 20Two teenagers are dressed in military uniformHe was reported to be concerned after fellow exile Glushkov&rsquos sudden death - and said he no longer wanted to go back to Russia.But later he said he feared &ldquothe British secret service might&nbsp organise some sort of provocation against him.He told a pro-Kremlin newspaper: &ldquoHonestly today I would feel safer in Russia.&nbsp

title: Ku Klux Klan How black cop infiltrated the Klan
story: PHDICING WITH DEATH: Ron Stallworth as a Colorado Springs policeman in 1979As crosses burned on front lawns and KKK killers terrorised blacks he risked his life to become a Klan chapter chief.Stallworth won the trust of the organisation's Grand Wizard David Duke while secretly thwarting the Klan's plans for bombings, armed assaults and racial attacks. It was all in a day's work for the detective except for one small detail: Ron Stallworth is black.His extraordinary penetration of the violent heart of America's hardcore racists is told in film director Spike Lee's new thriller BlacKkKlansman, just announced as an official American entry in the Cannes Film Festival and coming to British screens later this year.                Ku Klux Klan leader warns 'there will be more violence'                 ANGER student who dressed as KKK member will participate in boat racePHRon Stallworth&rsquos Ku Klux Klan membership cardIt was extremely dangerous to be a black man in the KKK, admits Stallworth, aged 65, in an exclusive interview with the .If I'd been exposed it could have all gone horribly wrong. The Klansmen were armed and there was always a peril.Stallworth, who has received numerous death threats since revealing how he fooled the Klan, was an undercover detective in Colorado Springs, Colorado - the city's first black officer - when he infiltrated the group.It was 1979, a year when the Klan killed five protesters in North Carolina and hung nooses from trees as threats across the Deep South.Stallworth was working in criminal intelligence and organised crime when he spotted a newspaper ad seeking members for a new KKK chapter.I wrote to the PO Box posing as a white racist.He explained that he hated blacks, Jews, Hiics, Chinese, Japanese, Italians - anyone who wasn't pure Aryan.I used every racial slur I knew to sound like one of them, he says.I gave them an untraceable phone number in my office but I wasn't thinking straight and used my real name, which could have been disastrous if they were any smarter but the Klan weren't the brightest bulbs in the socket.ALAMYFULL OF HATE: KKK Grand Wizard David Duke in 1978A week later a Klan organiser phoned, asking why Stallworth wanted to join.I said my sister is dating a n***** and every time he puts his filthy hands on her white body it makes me mad. And I want to stop that happening again.BUT when Stallworth didn't hear back he went straight to the top.I phoned the KKK Grand Wizard David Duke in Louisiana and asked why my membership was being delayed. He said my application was on his desk and promised to deal with it personally.It was the first of many conversations with David Duke. We talked about his family, the weather and about his political ambitions.Once I asked him, 'How do you know that you're not speaking with a n***** who's pretending to be white just to fool you?' He said, 'N****** don't talk like white folk. We say How are you but a n***** says, How are-a you. It gives them away.'I couldn't help laughing. Sometimes my sergeant would listen to me spouting racial slurs, saying how much I hated n****** and he would laugh so hard he had to leave the room.But it was no laughing matter when the KKK wanted to meet their new recruit.They wanted to know what I looked like so I described one of my fellow undercover detectives, whom I'll call 'Chuck' to protect his identity.In Spike Lee's movie Chuck is played by Star Wars' nefarious Adam Driver.When it came to meetings I'd send Chuck and briefed him on all the phone calls and plans we had made. Then after meeting the Klan posing as Stallworth he would tell me what happened.For more than seven months we infiltrated the local Klan, exposing their criminal plans.Corbis  GettyStallworth's investigation ended when he was asked to head the local Klan chapterThere were two gay bars in town that they wanted to bomb and the Klan had military members with explosives experience so the threat was real.Two Klansmen were working for NORAD monitoring US air space for missile attacks. I contacted the Pentagon and the next day they were reassigned to a posting near the North Pole.The Klan wanted to steal assault weapons from the nearby US army base at Fort Carson to use in attacks but I made sure that we talked about it so long that nothing got done.They planned three cross burnings but I was able to secretly call in so many uniform police cars to each location that it scared the Klan off. Most of their criminal plans were thwarted by their own incompetence.But he pushed his luck to the limit when David Duke visited Colorado Springs and Stallworth was assigned as the Grand Wizard's police bodyguard.On the outside I was cool but on the inside I was sweating bullets, he says.I was worried that Duke would recognise my voice but he never made the connection. When we met I told him, 'I don't agree with your political philosophy but I've been assigned to keep you safe and I will do that.'He shook my hand and I asked if I could be photographed with him. When I put my arm on Duke's shoulders he angrily brushed it off but just as the photograph was taken I put my arm back on his shoulder.Duke lurched for the camera but I grabbed it first. As he tried to snatch it away I told him, 'If you touch me that's assault on a police officer, with a five-year sentence.' He and about 20 Klansman stared me down but I lived to keep the photograph - sadly now lost.The undercover investigation ended when Stallworth was asked to accept leadership of the local Klan chapter.They said I had proven a loyal and capable Klansman, he laughs.But my police chief said we had to end the operation because we might be bordering on entrapment. That night the Klan burned a cross on a lawn in Colorado Springs and I wasn't there to stop it.Stallworth still has his red KKK membership card signed by Duke - It's in my wallet - and his framed certificate of membership.But he never received his white hood: The police department refused to approve the expense.When he penned his memoir Black Klansman, due to be published in the UK this year, the Klan turned on him.The FBI warned me that there were eight pages of online threats, people wanting to lynch me.Stallworth is now retired and living in El Paso, Texas, with his wife Patsy and served as a consultant on the movie.I hope it alerts people to the continuing danger of the Klan, he says. The KKK is still active across America and there is always the potential for them to strike at me if this film makes me a target.To pre-order Black Klansman by Ron Stallworth, published by Century Publishing at &pound12.99 on June 5, call the Express Bookshop with your debitcredit card on 01872 562310 or order online at expressbookshop.co.uk UK delivery is free.
